abstract.p: Dale Anglund letter on Dudley Clendinen's Sept 2 article urges steps to aid families providing long-term care at home for elderly ill

block.p: Re ''The Crisis in Providing Care for the Elderly Ill,'' by Dudley Clendinen (Editorial Observer, Sept. 2):

Mr. Clendinen writes that 80 percent of long-term care is given by families in a home setting. However, the caregiving family receives little formal recognition and often faces financial ruin. Failure to attend to the needs of families providing long-term care for their elderly results in caregiver ''burnout.'' Thus, more family members turn to institutional alternatives.
Re ''The Crisis in Providing Care for the Elderly Ill,'' by Dudley Clendinen (Editorial Observer, Sept. 2):

Mr. Clendinen writes that 80 percent of long-term care is given by families in a home setting. However, the caregiving family receives little formal recognition and often faces financial ruin. Failure to attend to the needs of families providing long-term care for their elderly results in caregiver ''burnout.'' Thus, more family members turn to institutional alternatives.

The existing policy should be examined. Combining estate taxes and the Medicare surplus could finance a policy supporting long-term care. In an election year this issue could affect the votes of millions of caregiving families.
